instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no video
threads.message:
Computer came in after red wine was spilled on it the night before. Inspected the board and replaced all corroded components. Then applied power and got a spinning fan without chime or video. Fan went high and stayed high. Then after cleaning a bit I noticed that traces from <RESISTOR>R5177</RESISTOR>/78 to SMC were shot. I repaired the traces here and still had the same issue. Figured if the traces to SMC were that badly burnt that the SMC was most likely fucked as well. I then replaced the SMC and the board booted normally with chime and video but no backlight. Upon troubleshooting that backlight circuit I noticed a small white dot in F7700. Tested for continuity and found the fuse was dead, as this was one of the areas hit with liquid so it wasn't a surprise. After replacing the fuse and checking for short I applied power I got very faint backlight for a split second then it went off. This caused F7700 to go dead again or maybe the fuse was bad, Im not sure. Replaced F7700 again and I now have 8.56V on both sides. Only problem is now I am back to no chime and no video.

PPBUS -8.58V
PP3V42 -3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 8.58V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 16.5V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
CPUVCORE - 1.6V
USB Mouse lights up.
Was able to PRAM with external KB before but now I cant really tell.
Is not doing 1,2,3 fan spin at the moment.

Damaged areas were <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> area, Bottom of SMC, <TRANSISTOR>Q3025</TRANSISTOR> area, <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> & <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> area, <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> area and F7700 area.
Confused because everything was working before I replaced the fuse and I have a really hard time with "No video, no chime. Coincidence?

Thanks in advance. Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no video
threads.message: Corroded traces/resistors to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>? J6100 corrosion? <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and traces to Xtal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no video
threads.message:
Hi Duke. 
Traces/Resistors look good although on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, pins 5&6 are stuck at 3.3V. Shouldn't the fluctuate, then land at 0? J6100 itself didnt have any corrosion but probe points under <TRANSISTOR>Q5830</TRANSISTOR> were red so I replaced it as well as <CAPACITOR>C5830</CAPACITOR>.  

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>
pin 1 - 3.3
pin 2 - 3.3
pin 3 - .931 ( I checked with known good working and got 0.20- 0.45.
pin 4 - 0.8 - 1.1
pin 5 - 3.3V
pin 6 - 1.184
pin 7 - GND
pin 8 - .564
pin 9 - 0
pin 10 - GND
pin 11 - GND
pin 12 - .438
pin 13 - 3.44
pin 14 - 3.3
pin 15 - 1.66
pin 16 - GND

Traces to XTAL from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>? I dont see, please advise. 

Thanks Duke.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no video
threads.message: <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> to Y1905 traces. Replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> if in doubt cause pin 3 should match a working board of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no video
threads.message:
Sooooooooo. I think I know what the issue is but, unfortunately I dont think its a repairable one. LOL.

After not really getting anywhere with this board (mainly because I suck when it comes to anything to do with clock/bios) I decided to put it in the cleaner to get a better look at it. Well that did help because I found a tiny hole I didnt see before in (TP) <SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL>. I checked for continuity back to <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> but there isn't any. The TP is too frail and I cant seem to get a wire on it. So I think Im Fucked seeing that this is the only way to access this line. Thanks anyway for your help Duke. Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no video
threads.message: Dont solder a wire. Expose the via copper "dot" and put a 0.3mm solder ball on it and try if it wants to flow onto it. Then put another ball there to create some more "flesh" and flow a really fine wire into it.
